channel.title: üß† Project management ‚Ä¢ notes on
channel.description: Recent content in üß† Project management ‚Ä¢ notes on

item.title: Absolute reference
item.description: A reference within a Function that is locked so that rows and columns won‚Äôt change if the function is copied.

item.title: Acceptance criteria
item.description: The checklist you will use to decide whether the User stories are done. Link: Definition of done

item.title: Access control
item.description: Features such as password protection, user permissions, and encryption that are used to protect a piece of information/tool.

item.title: Accuracy
item.description: The degree to which data conforms to the actual entity being measured or described.

item.title: Action-oriented question
item.description: A question whose answers lead to change.

item.title: Actors
item.description: Topics: Project manager Customers Portfolio manager Program manager Project sponsor Project team Stakeholders T-shaped team Team Team members Users Workgroups

item.title: Aggregation
item.description: The process of collecting or gathering many separate pieces into a whole.

item.title: Agile
item.description: Features: Able to move quickly and easily Flexibility and the willingness and ability to change and adapt Done in pieces Agile project phases overlap and tasks are completed in iterations, which in Scrum are called Sprints.

item.title: Agile manifesto
item.description: Values of the Agile manifesto: Individuals and interactions, over processes and tools Working software, over comprehensive documentation Customer collaboration over contract negotiation Responding to change, over following a plan Individuals and interactions, over processes and tools Working software, over comprehensive documentation Customer collaboration over contract negotiation Responding to change, over following a plan Twelve Principles Categories:

item.title: Agile Project Management
item.description: Topics: Applying agile Scrum Agile Agile manifesto Business agility DevOps Disciplined Agile Delivery (DAD) Distinguishing Agile from Waterfall Extreme programming (XP) History of agile Interview questions Kanban Large-Scale Scrum (LeSS) Mission Scale agile Scaled Agile Framework (SAFe) Scrum of Scrums The Spotify Model VUCA Work in Progress

item.title: Agile team challenges
item.description: Challanges: Value delivery Business collaboration Team dynamics and culture Value delivery [Agile manifesto](danielesalvatore/project-management/agile-project-management/agile-manifesto.md#Value delivery) Signs: Missing expected delivery dates Burned out Too many items “in progress” Work in Progress Solutions:

item.title: Air cover
item.description: Though the needs and requests of your Stakeholders are crucial to the project‚Äôs success, there may come a time when you, as Project manager, will need to prioritize the needs of your team over the wants of your stakeholders.

item.title: Algorithm
item.description: A process or set of rules to be followed for a specific task.

item.title: Aliasing
item.description: Temporarily naming a table or column in a query to make it easier to read and write.

item.title: Alignment with business objective
item.description: Always ensure that the Data you have is aligned with your

item.title: Analysis phases
item.description: Phases: Transform Data Performing a calculation Identify relationships or find patterns Format and adjust Data Organize Data Get input from others Comparing data to external resources

item.title: Analyst tools
item.description: Tools: Spreadsheet MS Excel Google Spreadsheet Formula Function Query language A computer programming language used to communicate with a database SQL to query Database Visualization tools Tableau Looker

item.title: Analytical skills
item.description: Analytical skills are qualities and characteristics associated with solving problems using facts. Curiosity Understanding of context how you group things into categories Having a technical mindset The ability to break things down into smaller steps or pieces and work with them in and orderly and logical ways Data design How you organize information Data strategy management of the people, processes, and tools used in data analysis

item.title: Analytical thinking
item.description: Analytical thinking involves identifying and defining a problem and then solving it by using data in an organized, step-by-step manner.

item.title: Analyze
item.description: Absolute reference Accuracy Action-oriented question Aggregation Aliasing Analysis phases Compatibility Completeness Consistency Currency Estimated response rate Incomplete data Incorrect (inaccurate) data Redundancy Reframing Relevant question Validity

item.title: Applying agile
item.description: Topics: Agile team challenges Coaching an Agile team Coaching versus managing in Agile Common Agile coaching challenges Introducing Agile to an organization Release plans Value Value roadmap Value-driven delivery

item.title: Applying influence in negotiations
item.description: References: Influencing Coalition A temporary alliance or partnering of individuals or groups in order to achieve a common purpose or to engage in a joint activity.

item.title: Ask
item.description: Algorithm Big data Data triumphs and disasters Decision-making types Mathematical thinking Metric Pivot table Problem Problem types Qualitative and quantitative data Questions to avoid Report Scope of Work Small data SMART questions Structured data

item.title: Attribute
item.description: A characteristic or quality of data used to label a column in a table

item.title: Avoiding ethical traps in procurements
item.description: Understanding ethical traps An ethical trap is an ethical dilemma that causes us to make a certain decision without regard for our ethical principles.

item.title: Avoiding misleading or deceptive charts
item.description: Cutting off the y-axis Changing the scale on the y-axis can make the differences between different groups in your data seem more dramatic, even if the difference is actually quite small.

item.title: Big data
item.description: Large, complex Dataset typically involving long periods of time, which enable Data analyst to address far-reaching business problems Characteristics: Large and less-specific Long time-period Usually kept in a database and queried Takes a lot of effort to collect, store, manage, sort, and visually represent

item.title: Breaking down barriers
item.description: A project manager adds value to a project when they break down barriers, allow their team to innovate new ways to do things, and empower them to share ideas.

item.title: Budget
item.description: Budgeting is the process of creating a plan to spend your money. In project management, this is considered a deliverable, a success metric.

item.title: Budget challenges
item.description: Challanges: Budget pre-allocation Inaccurately calculating Total Cost of Ownership (TCO) Scope creep Budget pre-allocation The budget is set before the start of the project.

item.title: Buffers
item.description: Extra time added to the end of a task or project to account for unexpected slowdowns or delays in work progress.

item.title: Building a great team
item.description: Biggest project asset. Build on top of the skills needed for a project, as well as the resource available. Understanding the Customers requirements helps shape the skills needed for a team.

item.title: Burndown chart
item.description: A burndown chart is a line chart that measures the time against the amount of work done and the amount of work remaining.

item.title: Business agility
item.description: Incorporating Agile principles into the wide sphere of management. Benefit: Adopted to thrive in high VUCA environments.

item.title: Business task
item.description: A business task is the question or Problem data analysis resolves for a business

item.title: Buy-in
item.description: The process of involving these people in decision-making to hopefully reach a broader consensus on the organization‚Äôs future. Stakeholder analysis enables project managers to do:

item.title: Capacity
item.description: The amount of work that the people or resources assigned to the project can reasonably complete in a set period.

item.title: Capacity planning
item.description: Refers to the act of allocating people and Project resources to project tasks and determining whether or not you have the necessary resources required to complete the work on time.

item.title: CAPEX and OPEX
item.description: Types: CAPEX OPEX Organizations have a number of different types of expenses, from the wages they pay their employees to the cost of materials for their products.

item.title: Cash flow
item.description: Cash flow is the inflow and outflow of cash on your project. As a project manager, this is important to understand because you need funding (cash into your project) to keep your project running.

item.title: Change
item.description: A change is anything that alters or impacts the tasks, structures, or processes within a project. Types of changes: New or changing Tasks dependencies Changing priority.

item.title: Change management
item.description: The process of delivering your complete product and getting people to adopt it. To understand that every project produces a change, let you plan for the change itself.

item.title: Charts
item.description: Charts: Column chart Histogram Density plot Line chart Pie chart Bar char Scattered plot Heatmap YouTube video to help you choose the best chart: https://www.

item.title: Clean data
item.description: Data that is complete, correct, and relevant to the problem you’re trying to solve. Opposite: Dirty data Data-cleaning pitfalls Pitfalls:

item.title: Close the project
item.description: Closing out your project to capture any lessons learned. Goals Ensure all tasks have been completed Confirm acceptance of the project outcome

item.title: Closeout report
item.description: A closeout report is a document written by Project manager for Project manager It is a blueprint to document what the team did, how they did it, and what they delivered It provides an evaluation of the quality of work It evaluates the project’s performance with respect to budget and schedule Confirms the project is done Definition of done Summarizes the Project deliverables, Success criteria, feedback, lesson learned, and next steps Serves as a reference document for the organization Benefits for the project team

item.title: Closing a project
item.description: Topics: Closeout report The closing process for the project manager The closing process for the team Impact reporting Importance of project closure Project closing Projects to avoid

item.title: Coaching an Agile team
item.description: Coaching: Design the “plays” with the team Provide feedback to the team Celebrate and learn with the team Design the “plays” with the team Although the Scrum Master owns the playbook of Scrum, it should be created with the whole team.

item.title: Coaching versus managing in Agile
item.description: Management is about giving direction, while coaching is about teaching. Managing Coaching Managing Project manager’s responsibilities In Agile teams are self-organizing [Agile manifesto](danielesalvatore/project-management/agile-project-management/agile-manifesto.

item.title: Common Agile coaching challenges
item.description: Common challenges: Managing a stable Product roadmap Incomplete implementation of Scrum Experiencing a lack of stability within the team Managing a stable product roadmap Unstable roadmap causes:

item.title: Common communication tools
item.description: Tools: Messaging Virtual meetings Work and management collaboration tools Messaging Principles of effective email writing Virtual meetings Suitable for remote work.

item.title: Common procurement documentation
item.description: Docs: Non-Disclosure Agreement (NDA) Request for Proposal (RFP) Statement of Work (SoW) Non-Disclosure Agreement (NDA) Used in the Initiating phase A document that keeps confidential information within the organization Request for Proposal (RFP) Used in the Selecting phase A document that outlines the details of the project, and it is meant to be passed to Vendors.

item.title: Communicate risks to stakeholders
item.description: If you don’t ell your stakeholders about important risks, they may be less equipped to help you if an issue arises.

item.title: Communicating project problems
item.description: Communicating project problems is a part of the job of the Project manager. It’s also Project manager’s responsibility to synthesize relevant information from multiple sources into a coherent summary that clearly communicates the issue.

item.title: Communication
item.description: The flow of information and includes what is shared, how it’s shared, and with whom. Communication needs to happen throughout the entire life cycle of the project.

item.title: Communication plan
item.description: It organizes and documents the process, types, and communication expectations for the project. A communication plan must include: What needs to be communicated Who needs to communicate Refer to the RACI chart and Stakeholder analysis for the list of recipients When communication needs to happen Why and how to communicate Where the information being communicated is stored Developing a communication plan Planning communications upfront

item.title: Compatibility
item.description: How well two or more Dataset are able to work together

item.title: Completeness
item.description: The degree to which Data contains all desired components or measures.

item.title: Confidence interval
item.description: The range of possible values that the population‚Äôs result would be at the Confidence level of the study. This range is the sample result +/- the margin of error.

item.title: Confidence level
item.description: How confident you are in the survey results. The probability that your Sample accurately reflects the greater Population For example, a 95% confidence level means that if you were to run the same survey 100 times, you would get similar results 95 of those 100 times.

item.title: Consent
item.description: The aspect of Data ethics that presumes an individual‚Äôs right to know how and why their personal data will be used before agreeing to provide it.

item.title: Consistency
item.description: The degree to which Data is repeatable from different points of entry or collection.

item.title: Context
item.description: Context is the condition in which something exists or happens. Ref: Data

item.title: Contingency reserves
item.description: Sometimes, a project hits a snag and incurs additional expenses. One way to prepare for unplanned costs is by using contingency reserves.

item.title: Continuous data
item.description: Data that is measured and can have almost any numeric value. Opposite: Discrete data

item.title: Continuous improvements
item.description: An ongoing effort to improve products or services It begins with recognizing when processes and tasks need to be: Created Eliminated Improved Process improvements The practices of identifying, analyzing, and improving existing processes to enhance the performance of your team and develop best practices, or optimize consumer experiences.

item.title: Corporate and project governance
item.description: Governance in business is the management framework within which decisions are made and accountability and responsibility are determined. Governance is understanding who is in change.

item.title: Cost variance
item.description: The difference between the actual cost and the budgeted cost.

item.title: Cost-benefit analysis
item.description: It can minimize the risks and maximize gains for projects and organizations. It uses objective data, it can help reduce biases and keep stakeholders’ self-interest from influencing decisions.

item.title: Creating a project budget
item.description: Techniques: Historical data Review past projects similar to the new one Leverage experts Gather experts’ insights about the project budget Bottom-up Think about all the components of a project, from the beginning to the end Ask vendors for quotes Confirm accuracy Double-check Baseline the budget It is the dollar amount that you’ll use to measure against, to find out if you’re on track or not, and to measure the success of your project.

item.title: Critical path
item.description: The list of project milestones you must reach to meet the project goal on schedule, as well as the mandatory task that contributes to the completion of each milestone.

item.title: Currency
item.description: The aspect of Data ethics that presumes individuals should be aware of financial transactions resulting from the use of their personal data and the scale of those transactions

item.title: Curse of knowledge
item.description: Because you know something, it can be difficult to imagine your audience not knowing it.

item.title: Customer relationships with communication skills
item.description: Use Soft skills. Ask open-ended questions and actively listen to understand the customer’s current state versus the desired state. Set clear expectations about when you’ll communicate certain things to customers.

item.title: Customers
item.description: In the field of project management, the word ‚Äúcustomer‚Äù refers to a person or an organization that defines the requirements of the project and sets important guidelines, such as Budget and deadlines.

item.title: Daily Stand-up
item.description: This is where the team meets for 15 minutes or less every day of the Sprint to inspect their progress toward their goal.

item.title: Dashboard
item.description: Type of user interface that provides a snapshot view of your project’s progress or performance. Monitors live incoming data. Pros and cons Pros:

item.title: Data
item.description: A collection of facts. Data > Information > Knowledge “Data! Data! Data!… I can’t make bricks without clay!” Sherlock Holmes via Sir Arthur Conan Doyle

item.title: Data analysis
item.description: Data analysis is the collection, transformation, and organization of data to draw conclusions, make predictions and drive informed decision-making.

item.title: Data analysis phases
item.description: Ask Identify/Define the problem and confirm Stakeholders expectations Prepare Collect and store data for analysis Process Clean and transform data to ensure the integrity Analyze Use data analysis tools to draw conclusions Share Interpret and communicate results to others to make data-driven decisions Act Put your insights to work in order to solve the original problem

item.title: Data analyst
item.description: It is someone who collects, transforms, and organizes data in order to help make informed decisions. It is the collection of Data in order to draw conclusions and make data-informed decisions.

item.title: Data analytics
item.description: The science of Data

item.title: Data bias
item.description: A type of error that systematically skews results in a certain direction. Related: Fairness Types of data bias Types

item.title: Data collection considerations
item.description: Considerations: How the data will be collected Chose data sources First-party data Second-party data Third-party data Decide what data to use How much data to collect Population Select the right data type Determine the time frame

item.title: Data design
item.description: How information is organized.

item.title: Data ecosystems
item.description: The data ecosystems are the various elements that interact with one another in order to produce, manage, store, organize, analyze and share data.

item.title: Data elements
item.description: Pieces of information, such as people’s names, account numbers and addresses.

item.title: Data engineers
item.description: Transform data into a useful format for analysis and give it a reliable infrastructure.

item.title: Data ethics
item.description: Data ethics is well-founded standards of right and wrong that dictate how data is collected, shared, and used. For instance, the data a Project manager collects during a project can contain PII (personally identifiable information).

item.title: Data governance
item.description: A process to ensure the formal management of a company’s data assets. Refs: Data

item.title: Data integrity
item.description: The accuracy, completeness, consistency, and trustworthiness of the Data throughout its lifecycle. A strong analysis depends on the integrity of the data.

item.title: Data interoperability
item.description: The ability of data systems and services to openly connect and share data. Requirements: Be available and accessible to the public as a complete dataset Be provided under terms that allow it to be reused and redistributed Allow universal participation so that anyone can use, reuse, and redistribute the data Refs:

item.title: Data life cycle
item.description: Data life cycle: Planning Decide what kind of data is needed, how it will be managed, and who will be responsible for it.

item.title: Data manipulation
item.description: The process of changing Data to make it more organized and easier to read.

item.title: Data merging
item.description: The process of combining two or more Dataset into a single one.

item.title: Data model
item.description: A model that is used for organizing Data elements and how they relate to one another. Conceptual data modeling gives a high-level view of the data structure, such as how data interacts across an organization.

item.title: Data privacy
item.description: Preserving a data subject’s information and activity any time a data transaction occurs. Personal rights: protection from unauthorized access to our private data, freedom from inappropriate use of our data, the right to inspect, update, or correct our data, ability to give consent to use our data, legal right to access our data.

item.title: Data replication
item.description: It is the process of storing Data in multiple locations.

item.title: Data science
item.description: Data science is creating new ways of modeling and understanding the unknown by using raw data.

item.title: Data security
item.description: Data security means protecting data from unauthorized access or corruption by putting safety measures in place. Usually the purpose of data security is to keep unauthorized users from accessing or viewing sensitive data.

item.title: Data transfer
item.description: The process of copying Data from a storage device to memory or from one computer to another.

item.title: Data triumphs and disasters
item.description: This reading focuses on why accurate interpretation of data is key to data-driven decisions. You have been learning why data is such a powerful business tool and how data analysts help their companies make data-driven decisions for great results.

item.title: Data type
item.description: A specific kind of Data attribute that tells what kind of value the data is. Examples in spreadsheets: Number Text or string Boolean

item.title: Data validation
item.description: A tool for checking the accuracy and quality of Data before adding or importing it.

item.title: Data visualization
item.description: It is the graphical representation of information to facilitate understanding. Filter information by focusing the audience on the most important data points and insights.

item.title: Data visualization tools
item.description: Tools: Data Analysts/Share/Data visualization/Dashboard Burndown chart Charts

item.title: Data warehousing specialists
item.description: Develop processes and procedures to effectively store and organize data.

item.title: Data-driven decision-making
item.description: Data-driven decision-making is using facts to guide business strategy. Use Analytical skills to tap into all the potential of data-driven decision-making.

item.title: Data-driven improvement frameworks
item.description: Techniques used to make decisions based on actual data. DMAIC PDCA

item.title: Database
item.description: A database is a collection of data stored in a computer system. Relational database A database that contains a series of related tables that can be connected via their relationship.

item.title: Dataset
item.description: A dataset is a collection of Data that can be manipulated or analyzed as one unit

item.title: Decision-making types
item.description: Data-driven decision-making Data-inspired decision making Explores different data sources to find out what they have in common

item.title: Definition of done
item.description: Definition of Done refers to an agreed-upon set of items that must be completed before our user story or Backlog item can be considered complete.

item.title: Delegation
item.description: Project manager use delegation to add value to their teams and organizations by matching tasks to individuals who can best complete the work.

item.title: Dependency management
item.description: The process of managing interrelated tasks ( Tasks dependencies) and resources within the project to ensure the overall Project is completed successfully, on time, and within Budget.

item.title: Design for 5 seconds
item.description: The idea is that your audience should understand your visual message in 5 seconds or less.

item.title: Design principles
item.description: Design principles Once you understand the pre-attentive attributes of data visualization, you can go on to design principles for creating effective visuals.

item.title: Design thinking
item.description: A process used to solve complex problems in a user-centric way. Phases Phases: Empathize Think about the emotions and needs of the targeted audience Define It helps you find your audience’s needs, their problems, and your insights.

item.title: Development team (or Developers)
item.description: The people who do the work to build the product. (5 to 9 people) The Development Team is responsible for how a team will deliver that product.

item.title: Deviation
item.description: Anything that alters your original course of action. Deviations from the project plan can be positive or negative.

item.title: DevOps
item.description: Combination of: Development Operations An organization and cultural movement that aims to increase the software delivery velocity, improve service reliability, and build shared ownership among software stakeholders.

item.title: Dirty data
item.description: Data that is incomplete, incorrect, or irrelevant to the problem you are trying to solve. Opposite: Clean data Types:

item.title: Disciplined Agile Delivery (DAD)
item.description: Disciplined Agile Delivery (DAD) is a hybrid approach that combines the strategies from various Agile frameworks, including Kanban, LeSS, Lean Development, Extreme Programming, Agile Modeling, and more.

item.title: Discrete data
item.description: Data that is counted and has a limited number of values.

item.title: Distinguishing Agile from Waterfall
item.description: Agile is an iterative process, and Waterfall is more linear. Both have their merits, depending on the project. Agile was created in response to the strict linear process of Waterfall

item.title: DMAIC
item.description: DMAIC: Define Measure Conduct performance metrics and data collection Analyze Improve Control

item.title: Documentation
item.description: Documentation storage and sharing are very important. Having plans in one place makes communication quicker, easier, and more streamlined. Documenting and organizing plans provides visibility and accountability.

item.title: Domain knowledge
item.description: Knowledge of a specific industry, topic, or activity.

item.title: Duration
item.description: The total time it takes to complete the project from start to finish

item.title: Dynamic visualizations
item.description: Visualizations that are interactive or change over time.

item.title: Effective communication
item.description: You’ll need to communicate certain information to your team multiple times and in various ways. Some people learn by listening Some people learn by watching Some people learn by doing Questions to ask yourself:

item.title: Effective data visualization
item.description: Frameworks for organizing your thoughts about visualization Frameworks can help you organize your thoughts about data visualization and give you a useful checklist to reference.

item.title: Effective meetings
item.description: Features: Structured Intentional Collaborative Inclusive Structured Start and end on time Carefully selected attendees Prioritized topics within an agenda Timeboxed: setting a time limit for each topic Designated notetaker Intentional Cleary stated purpose and expectations Everyone understands why they’re meeting Your meeting’s purpose, or goal, describes the reason you’re meeting and what you’d like to achieve.

item.title: Effective presentation techniques
item.description: Techniques: Be precise Identify the problem you’re solving for your audience Remove any content that dilutes your message Design for 5 seconds Be flexible Consider the approach you’d take if you had to shorten your presentation unexpectedly Practice avoiding mistakes that could distract from your message Identify and come up with answers to potential audience questions Image and prepare for possible objections Be memorable Use stories or repetition to help your audience remember information Beware of your body language Posture Tone of voice Pace Eye contact Warm and friendly facial expressions Confidence

item.title: Effective teams
item.description: Topics: Air cover Ethical and inclusive leadership High-functioning teams Influencing Project teamwork Sources of power to influence Steps to effective influencing Team development Team dynamics Team effectiveness factors Teamwork

item.title: Effort estimations
item.description: A prediction of the amount and difficulty of active work required to complete a task. The time required for a person to complete an activity.

item.title: Elements for effective visuals
item.description: Elements: Clear meaning Sophisticated use of contrast Refined execution

item.title: Elements of art
item.description: Elements: Line Shape Color Space Movement

item.title: Empiricism
item.description: Empiricism is the idea that true knowledge comes from actual, lived experience. Based on the same Scrum pillars of Scrum.

item.title: Engagement
item.description: Capturing and holding someone‚Äôs interest and attention during a data presentation

item.title: Epic
item.description: A group of collection of User stories.

item.title: Escalation
item.description: The process of enlisting the help of higher-level project leadership or management to remove an obstacle, clarify or reinforce priorities, and validate the next steps.

item.title: Estimated response rate
item.description: The average number of people who typically complete a survey.

item.title: Estimates
item.description: Through estimation, we can find out how much work we have ahead of us. Relative estimations Instead of trying to determine exactly how long a task will take, we compare the effort of that task to another task, and that becomes the estimate.

item.title: Estimations
item.description: Types: Time estimations Effort estimations Time estimations A prediction of the total amount of time required to complete a task.

item.title: Ethical and inclusive leadership
item.description: Ethical leadership A form of leadership that promotes and values honesty, justice, respect, community, and integrity. Promoting ethical leadership: Defining and aligning values within your team Demonstrating how adhering to those values benefits the Mission of the organization Ethical leadership’s aim is to create forums where employees’ concerns can be heard.

item.title: Ethics
item.description: Ethics is well-founded standards of right and wrong that prescribe what humans ought to do, usually in terms of rights, obligations, benefits to society, fairness, or specific virtues.

item.title: Evaluation
item.description: Evaluation is a form of research designed to promote learning and inform decisions. It also provides accountability. It involves observing, measuring, and then comparing your findings to a set of agreed-upon criteria.

item.title: Evaluation presentation
item.description: Evaluation presentation process: Consider your audience What’s most meaningful to them? Present the same data in different ways Create a detailed evaluation report Summarize the information into the most appropriate format for a given audience Steps should you take to start analyzing data to present:

item.title: Execute & complete tasks
item.description: Executing project tasks and addressing any issues that arise Goals Project manager: manage the progress Team: to complete the tasks

item.title: Executive summary
item.description: An executive summary is a few sentences to a paragraph that describes¬†the project’s purpose and outcome.¬†It provides an overview of¬†the main points of a larger report.

item.title: External data
item.description: Data that lives and is generated outside of an organization.

item.title: Extreme programming (XP)
item.description: Project management methodologies Aims to improve product quality and the ability to respond to changing customer needs Takes best practices for the development process to “extreme” levels XP wants to ensure that all of the pieces of the product will fit together properly.

item.title: Fairness
item.description: A quality of Data analysis that does not create or reinforce bias Examples: Making sure a sample population represents all groups Considering systematic factors that may influence data Factoring in social contexts that could create bias in conclusions Collect the data in an objective way Think through the “who, what, where, when, how, and why” of your data Unfair question A question that makes assumptions or is difficult to answer honestly

item.title: Feedback surveys
item.description: Surveys are tools you can use to evaluate and measure the quality of a project process, goal, or deliverable. A survey in which users provide feedback on features of your product that they like or dislike.

item.title: First-party data
item.description: Data collected by an individual or group using their own resources.

item.title: Fixe whys
item.description: Five whys (or 5 whys) is an iterative interrogative technique used to explore the cause-and-effect relationships underlying a particular problem. The primary goal of the technique is to determine the root cause of a defect or problem by repeating the question “Why?

item.title: Fixed contracts
item.description: Paid for when certain milestones are reached.

item.title: Float or Slack
item.description: Float, or slack, is the amount of time you can wait to begin a task before it impacts the project schedule and threatens the project outcome

item.title: Focus on the customers
item.description: Customers are a key element to success in any business. To successfully deliver a project, it has to meet customers‚Äô standards.

item.title: Formula
item.description: A set of instructions used to perform a calculation using the data in a spreadsheet

item.title: Fostering relationships and communication
item.description: The project managers who add the most value are the ones who take the time to build relationships, communicate, and treat others with consideration and respect.

item.title: Foundations
item.description: Analyst tools Analytical skills Analytical thinking Attribute Business task Context Data Data analyst Data analysis Data design Data ecosystems Data life cycle Data science Data-driven decision-making Database Fairness Formula Function Gap analysis Observation Operators Quartile Root cause Subject-matter experts

item.title: Foundations of Project Management
item.description: Possible natural path: Project manager > Program Manager > Portfolio Manager Topics: Actors Organizational structure and culture Project Project management methodologies Project deliverables Project goals

item.title: Function
item.description: A preset command that automatically performs a specified process or task using the data in a spreadsheet

item.title: Further reading
item.description: Reading: The beauty of data visualization: In this video, David McCandless explains the need for design to not just be beautiful, but for it to be meaningful as well.

item.title: Gantt chart
item.description: A horizontal bar chart that maps out a project schedule. Gantt charts are a highly visual representation of a project’s tasks, with clear breakdowns of who’s responsible for the work and when those tasks are due.

item.title: Gap analysis
item.description: Gap analysis is a method for examining and evaluating how a process works currently in order to get where you want to be in the future.

item.title: GDPR
item.description: GDPR: General Data Protection Regulation of the European Union

item.title: Getting accurate time estimates from your team
item.description: Soft skills for accurate estimations: Asking the right questions Use open-ended questions Questions that cannot be answered with a “Yes” or “No.

item.title: Going under budget
item.description: It may be considered as: That your initial estimates were inaccurate That you could have spent more on the project to provide extra resources

item.title: Good data
item.description: ROCCC: Reliable Original Comprehensive Current Citede

item.title: High-functioning teams
item.description: A Project manager helps build high-functioning team: Create systems that turn chaos into order Communicate and listen Promote trust and psychological safety Demonstrate empathy and create motivation Delegate responsibility and prioritize Celebrate team success Create systems that turn chaos into order Done this by creating, implementing, and improving: standardized, measurable, repeatable, and scalable workflows and processes for your Team.

item.title: History of agile
item.description: Agile project management An approach to project and team management that embodies “agility” and is based on the Agile Manifesto.

item.title: How to collect data
item.description: Ways: Interviews Observations Forms Questionnaires Surveys Cookies

item.title: Hypothesis
item.description: The theory you’re trying to prove or disprove with Data Analysts/Foundations/Data. Establishing the hypothesis early in the presentation will help your audience understand the data.

item.title: Hypothesis testing
item.description: A way to see if a survey or experiment has meaningful results.

item.title: Identifying and tracking dependencies
item.description: Tasks dependencies are often the greater source of Risk to a Project.

item.title: Impact
item.description: The impact is the damage a risk could cause if it occurs. The impact is determined on a scale of:

item.title: Impact reporting
item.description: The purpose of your impact report is to show your key Stakeholders the impact your project had on the organization. Project goals, objectives, Budget, schedules, and Key Performance Indicators (KPI) need to be determined at the beginning of your Project.

item.title: Importance of project closure
item.description: Project closing must meet these criteria to successfully close a project: Assurance all work is done Agreed-upon project management processes are executed Formal recognition and agreement that the project is done by key Stakeholders

item.title: Important data
item.description: Being aware of the different types of Data you have access to and knowing which Signal to respond to are key to deciding what data is most important.

item.title: Incomplete data
item.description: Data that is missing important fields.

item.title: Inconsistent data
item.description: Data that uses different formats to represent the same thing.

item.title: Incorrect (inaccurate) data
item.description: Data that is complete but inaccurate.

item.title: Incremental
item.description: Work is divided into smaller chunks that build on each other.

item.title: Influencing
item.description: The ability to alter another person’s thinking or behaviors. Leverage the Steps to effective influencing Keys Clarify measurable results SMART Find vital behaviors A vital behavior is an action an individual takes at a pivotal moment in the context of the change they are seeking.

item.title: Inherent risk
item.description: The inherent risk is the measure of risk, calculated by its Probability and Impact.

item.title: Initiate a project
item.description: Capturing the expectations of your customer Goals Define project goals Define resources, people, and project details Get project approval Questions Who are the stakeholders?

item.title: Insufficient data
item.description: Types: Data only from Data source Data that keeps updating Outdated data Geographically-limited data Ways to address insufficient data Ways:

item.title: Internal data
item.description: Data that lives within a company’s own systems. Opposite: External data

item.title: Interview questions
item.description: Questions: What’s the difference between Agile and¬†Waterfall project management? Distinguishing Agile from Waterfall Do they know it’s also about founding values that include customer collaboration, value delivery, and self-organizing teams?

item.title: Introducing Agile to an organization
item.description: Introducing Agile to an organization: Creating a sense of ownership Find an executive sponsor who also feels a sense of ownership for the change you’re creating.

item.title: Issue
item.description: A known or real problem that can affect the ability to complete a task.

item.title: Iterative
item.description: Some of the phases and tasks will overlap or happen at the same time that other tasks are being worked on.

item.title: Kanban
item.description: Project management methodologies Visualization: provides transparent visual feedback Ensures that the project team only accepts a sustainable amount of in-progress work Work in Progress Flow of work Kanban boards are a visual tool used to manage tasks and workflows.

item.title: Key components of a project budget
item.description: When creating a budget, a projecrt manager must account for: Understanding stakeholder needs Generally speaking a company wants to make money and save time This implies that a project must comes with a max cost to make profit Budgeting for surprise expenses Budget for contingency Maintaining adaptability Review and re-forecasting throughout the project Recalibrate the budget if necessary Resource cost rates The cost of a resource.

item.title: Key Performance Indicators (KPI)
item.description: A measurable value or metric that demonstrates how effective an organization is at achieving key objectives.

item.title: Kick-off meeting
item.description: The kick-off meeting is the first meeting in which a project team comes together to ground everyone in a shared vision, gain a shared understanding of the project’s goals and scope, and understand each person’s roles within the team.

item.title: Knowledge management
item.description: A way of ensuring that project data can be accessed in the future by others who need it for informing decisions or planning similar projects.

item.title: Large-Scale Scrum (LeSS)
item.description: Large-Scale Scrum (LeSS) is a framework that aims to maximize the Scrum team‚Äôs ability to deliver value and reduce waste in larger organizations.

item.title: Launching and landing a project
item.description: Launch Delivering the final result of your project to the client or user. Landing Measuring the success of your project using the success criteria established at the outset of the project.

item.title: Lean
item.description: Originated in the manufacturing world. The main principle is the removal of waste in an operation. By optimizing steps and eliminating waste, the only value is added at each phase of production.

item.title: Lean Six Sigma
item.description: It is the combination of two methodologies: Lean Six Sigma When the team feels value, motivation and productivity increase, and the whole process works more smoothly.

item.title: Linear
item.description: Linear The previous phase or task has to be completed before the next can start. Unlikely to include changes during the execution.

item.title: Long data
item.description: A Dataset in which each row is one time point per subject, so each subject has data in multiple rows

item.title: Maintaining a project budget
item.description: Monitoring the budget is crucial for a project manager to enforce accountability in terms of spending. Milestones are a great opportuninty to re-review the budget, to identify if anything needs to be reset or revisited throughhout the project.

item.title: Make a plan
item.description: Setting your project up for success with a plan Goals Create a Budget Set the Project schedule Establish your team Determine roles and responsibilities Plan for Risk and Change Establish communication Questions:

item.title: Management reserves
item.description: While contingency reserves are used to cover the costs of identified risks, management reserves are used to cover the costs of unidentified risks.

item.title: Managing project's scope
item.description: A change to any of these dimensions will affect the others.

item.title: Managing the project
item.description: A successful project manager sees the impacts of each process within the project and communicates those impacts to the team.

item.title: Margin error
item.description: The maximum amount that the sample results are expected to differ from those of the actual population. Since a Sample is used to represent a Population, the sample‚Äôs results are expected to differ from what the result would have been if you had surveyed the entire population.

item.title: Mathematical thinking
item.description: Linked to: Small data Big data

item.title: Measuring customer satisfaction
item.description: Measurements: Feedback surveys User acceptable tests (UAT)

item.title: Mentor
item.description: A professional who shares their knowledge, skills, and experience to help you develop and grow. Website: Score.org MicroMentor.org Mentorship A mentor helps you skill up.

item.title: Metadata
item.description: Data about data. It is used in database management to help data analysts interpret the contents of the data within a Database.

item.title: Metric
item.description: A metric is a single, quantifiable type of Data that can be used for measurement. Can be combined into Formula.

item.title: Milestones
item.description: An important point within the project schedule that indicates progress and usually signifies the completion of a deliverable or phase of the project.

item.title: Minimum Viable Product (MVP)
item.description: A version of a product with just enough features to satisfy early customers.

item.title: Mission
item.description: A mission is a short statement that stays constant for your team throughout the process and gives them something to work toward.

item.title: Myths about project managers
item.description: Myths: Myth: You have to be an expert in the field and have a lot of technical knowledge about the project.

item.title: Negotiating with empathy
item.description: Empathy Empathy is the ability to understand and feel what others are feeling. Tips for bringing empathy to your conversations listen with curiosity repeat what you think you heard connect with their experience recognize judgments recognize buffering avoid distractions Links:

item.title: Negotiation
item.description: Persuasion and negotiation are constructive tools to: Enhance communication Clarify wants and needs Achieve workable solutions for everyone involved View the people you are negotiating with as your colleagues and peers, not as opponents.

item.title: Networking
item.description: Professional relationship building. How to develop a network In this reading, you will be introduced to online and in-person opportunities to connect with other data analysts.

item.title: Nominal data
item.description: A type of qualitative Data Analysts/Foundations/Data that is categorized without a set order. Ref: Qualitative and quantitative data Opposite:

item.title: Observation
item.description: The attributes that describe a piece of data contained in a row of a table References: Attribute

item.title: OKR
item.description: OKR: Objectives and Key Results OKRs combine a goal and a metric to determine a measurable outcome. - Project goals - Project metrics

item.title: Online presence
item.description: Why: Help potential employers find you Make connections with other professional Learn and share data findings Participate in community events Tips:

item.title: Open data
item.description: Data that is available to the public.

item.title: Operators
item.description: A symbol that names the type of operation or calculation to be performed. Used within Formula.

item.title: Opportunity
item.description: An opportunity is a potentially positive outcome of a Risk. To identify an opportunity, apply the same phases of the Risk management phases.

item.title: Ordinal data
item.description: A type of qualitative Data with a set order or scale. Refs: Qualitative and quantitative data Nominal data

item.title: Organizational culture
item.description: Organizational culture: The values employees share, as well as the organization‚Äôs values, mission, and history Company‚Äôs personality It is related to how to manage a team and achieve your goal, if you show that your project aligns with the organization‚Äôs goals it‚Äôll be easier to get approvals and resources.

item.title: Organizational structure and culture
item.description: The way a company or organization is arranged or structured, who does what, and who reports to whom. Classic Functional or top-down structures Matrix Direct higher-ups and stakeholder‚Äôs from other departments or programs Authority has to do with your ability to make decisions for the project that impact the organization.

item.title: Organizational structures
item.description: How members of the organization relate to and interact with one another Classic structure Matrix structure Classic structure May find yourself with less authority and limited scope.

item.title: Organizing data
item.description: Benefits: Makes it easier to find and use Helps you avoid making mistakes during your analysis. Helps to protect it Refs:

item.title: Organizing project documentation
item.description: Have all of your project resources documented and linked so that you or anyone on the project can access what they need quickly.

item.title: Participating in change management
item.description: Participating in change management involves being empathic to the challenges of the change management process and supporting necessary changes throughout the project lifecycle.

item.title: PDCA
item.description: A four-step process that focuses on identifying a problem, fixing that issue, assessing whether the fix was successful, and find-tuning the final fix

item.title: PII (personally identifiable information)
item.description: Information that could be used to directly identify, contact, or locate an individual

item.title: Pivot table
item.description: A Data summarization tool that is used in the data processing. Pivot tables are used to summarize, sort, reorganize, group, count, total or average data stored in Database.

item.title: Planning fallacy
item.description: Introduced in 1977 by Daniel Kahneman and Amos Tversky, two behavioral economics. The planning fallacy describes our tendency to underestimate the amount of time it will take to complete a task, as well as the costs and risks associated with that task, due to optimism bias.

item.title: Population
item.description: All possible data values in a Dataset.

item.title: Portfolio
item.description: A collection of Project and Program across the whole organization. Links to: Portfolio manager

item.title: Portfolio manager
item.description: Responsible for managing multiple programs within the same organization to meet strategic initiatives. Looks at all projects and programs within an organization and prioritize work as necessary.

item.title: Powerful visualization
item.description: One of the biggest considerations when crating a Data visualization is where you’d like your audience to focus.

item.title: Prepare
item.description: Access control Continuous data Data bias Data collection considerations Data elements Data governance Data interoperability Data model Data privacy Data security Data type Discrete data Ethics External data First-party data GDPR Good data How to collect data Internal data Long data Mentor Metadata Networking Nominal data Online presence Open data Ordinal data Organizing data Population Sample Sampling bias Second-party data Sponsor Structured data Third-party data Unbiased sampling Unstructured data Wide data

item.title: Principles of effective email writing
item.description: Principles: State what you want clearly. Keep the content short and concise. Structure your writing. Check grammar, punctuation, and spelling.

item.title: Prioritization
item.description: Project manager add value to their teams and organizations through effective prioritization of tasks required to complete a project.

item.title: Probability
item.description: The likelihood that a risk will occur. The probability is determined on a scale of: high medium low

item.title: Problem
item.description: “If I were¬†given one hour to save the planet,¬†I would spend 59 minutes defining¬†the problem and one minute resolving it.

item.title: Problem types
item.description: Problem types: Making predictions It involved using data to make an informed decision about how things may be in the future Categorizing things It means assigning information to different groups or clusters based on comon features Spotting something unusual Identify data that is different from the norm Identifying themes Grouping categorized information into borader concepts Discovering connections Finding similar challanges faced by different entities and combining data and insights to address them Finding patterns Uising historical data to understand what happened in the past and is therefoew likely to happen again

item.title: Process
item.description: Alignment with business objective Clean data Confidence level Confidence level Consent Data engineers Data integrity Data manipulation Data merging Data replication Data transfer Data validation Data warehousing specialists Dirty data Hypothesis testing Insufficient data Margin error Random sampling Statistical power Statistical significance

item.title: Procurement
item.description: Obtaining all of the materials, services, and supplies required to complete the project. Also applied to: Vendors Procurement phases Common procurement documentation Avoiding ethical traps in procurements Topics:

item.title: Procurement phases
item.description: Steps: Initiating Selecting Contract writing Control Completing Initiating Define what help you may need Selecting Select what supply you need Contract writing Contracts are written, reviewed, and signed Control Check quality and agreement are met Completing Measure the success of the procurement Agile procurement management Collaborating with both the project team and the end supplier Emphasis on the relationship between these parties The project team plays a larger role in identifying what needs to be procured.

item.title: Product backlog
item.description: The central artifact in Scrum, where all possible ideas, deliverables, features, or tasks are captured for the team to work on.

item.title: Product increment
item.description: The product increment is what is produced after a given Sprint and is considered Releasable.

item.title: Product owner
item.description: Responsible for what the team builds. Build the right thing. Value-driven delivery Responsibilities The product owner is responsible for continuously maximizing the value of the product and the work of the team.

item.title: Product roadmap
item.description: Roadmap: A high-level view of the expected product and its requirements Estimated schedule for reaching milestones Benefits Clarifying the sequence of deliverables Showing teams how their efforts relate to the north-star vision.

item.title: Product vision
item.description: Product vision is when you set a vision, you’re making it clear what the team is responsible for and where your team’s boundaries are.

item.title: Program
item.description: A collection of Project. Links to: Program manager

item.title: Program manager
item.description: Manager of multiple projects that are part of a program. Manages projects aligned in terms of principles, similar to one another.

item.title: Project
item.description: A unique endeavor, and usually includes a set of unique deliverables. A temporary purist; has a beginning and an end.

item.title: Project budget best practices
item.description: Best practice: Reference historical data Utilize your team, mentors, or manager Time-phase your budget Check, check, and double-check Reference historical data Your project may be similar to a previous project your organization has worked on.

item.title: Project charter
item.description: Project charter A document that clearly defines the project and the Project goals and outlines what is needed to accomplish them.

item.title: Project closing
item.description: Project closing is the process performed to formally complete the project, the current phase, and contractual obligations. You can choose between a small, closing process at the end of each milestone, or a formal, larger comprehensive closing phase at the very end only.

item.title: Project data
item.description: Topics: Data Data Analysts/Foundations/Data analyst Duration Data ethics Duration Important data PII (personally identifiable information) Project data Project metrics Projections Qualitative data Quantitative data Signal Value of data

item.title: Project deliverables
item.description: Deliverables: The products or services that are created for the customer, client, or project sponsor What gets produced or presented at the end of a task, event, or process Help quantify and realize the impact of a project Goals are relative to the project; deliverables are relative to tasks.

item.title: Project execution
item.description: Topics: Continuous improvements Data visualization Effective communication Effective teams Project data Quality management Burndown chart Change Dependency management Deviation Escalation Gantt chart Identifying and tracking dependencies Product roadmap Retrospective Roadmap Techniques to help manage risks Tracking Tracking methods

item.title: Project goals
item.description: The desired output of a project. Well-defined goals are both specific and measurable.

item.title: Project initialization
item.description: Goals: Initiating the project Identifying Scope, Project goals, and Project deliverables Measure the success of a project Success criteria Identify Stakeholders Scoping project tools and resource Topics:

item.title: Project initialization key components
item.description: Components: Goals Scope Deliverables Success criteria Stakeholders Resources Goals The goal is what you‚Äôve been asked to do and what you‚Äôre trying to achieve Project goals Scope Scope definition: the process to define the work that needs to happen to complete the process Project scope Deliverables Products and services that you will create for your customer, client, or project sponsor Tangible or intangible Success criteria The standards by which you measure how successful a project was in reaching its goals Success criteria Stakeholders They‚Äôre people who both have an interest in, and are affected by, the completion and success of a project.

item.title: Project life cycle
item.description: The phases of a project: Initiate a project Make a plan Execute & complete tasks Close the project

item.title: Project management
item.description: The application of knowledge, skills, tools, and techniques to meet the project requirements and achieve the desired outcome. Index Foundations of Project Management Project initialization Project planning Project execution Agile Project Management Closing a project

item.title: Project management methodologies
item.description: A set of guiding principles and processes for owning a project through its life cycle Linear Waterfall Iterative Agile Lean Six Sigma Lean Six Sigma

item.title: Project Management Methodology
item.description: Topics: Iterative Lean Lean Six Sigma Linear Six Sigma Waterfall

item.title: Project Management Office
item.description: The Project Management Office (PMO) is a group within an organization that defines, sets, and helps maintain project management standards and processes.

item.title: Project manager
item.description: Shepherd projects from start to finish and serves as guides for their team, using their impeccable organizational and interpersonal skills every step of the way.

item.title: Project manager's skills
item.description: Skills Skills for successful project management: Enabling decision making Gather information from within and outside the team to make informed-decisions Communicating and escalating Documentation Project status reports Escalate risks to stakeholders Flexibility Flexible planning Stay cool under pressure and change is inevitable!

item.title: Project manager's responsibilities
item.description: Project manager’s responsibilities: Planning and organizing Making use of productivity tools and creating processes Create plans, timelines, schedules, and other forms of documentation to track project completion Managing tasks

item.title: Project metrics
item.description: Metrics: Productivity metrics Quality metrics Productivity metrics They allow you to track the effectiveness and efficiency of your project Milestones Tasks Projections Duration Quality metrics Metrics that relate to achieving acceptable outcomes Number of Change (inconsistency from the initial requirements of the project) Issue Cost variance

item.title: Project plan
item.description: A living document that includes the scope, milestones, and any project activity. The Project schedule estimates the time it’ll take to complete the project.

item.title: Project plan's Best practices
item.description: Best practices: Carefully review deliverables, milestones, and tasks. Divide any deliverable contained in the Project charter into milestones. Give yourself time to plan Use Effort estimations and Capacity planning to determine how long the project will take.

item.title: Project planning
item.description: Features: Understand the work needed to achieve your goals Coordinate efforts and timelines with other teams, contractors, and vendors

item.title: Project planning phases
item.description: Phases: Project initialization (prerequisites) Identify major milestones and assign tasks to owners Map project schedule and tasks using Gantt charts Estimate costs and create a budget Create a Statement of Work (SoW) Create a Risk management plan Create a communication plan Organize the project artifacts

item.title: Project proposal
item.description: A form of documentation that persuades a stakeholder to begin a project. A project proposal is created earlier than a Project charter

item.title: Project requirements
item.description: Conditions that must be met or tasks that must be finished to ensure the successful completion of the project. Project scope

item.title: Project resources
item.description: Kind of resources: Budget People Materials Budget An estimate of the amount of money a project will cost to complete.

item.title: Project schedule
item.description: An anchor of a good project plan is a clear schedule containing all the Tasks, their owners, and when they need to be completed.

item.title: Project scope
item.description: An agreed-upon understanding as to what is included or excluded from a project. The scope is also defined as the project boundaries.

item.title: Project sponsor
item.description: The person who‚Äôs accountable for the project and who ensures the project delivers the agreed upon business benefits. Sometimes they fund the project.

item.title: Project team
item.description: When choosing a team, consider: Required roles Team size As the team increases in size, communication becomes more difficult Necessary skilled Skills can be taught Availability Motivation

item.title: Project teamwork
item.description: Project teamwork Great Project manager Support people to do their best work Enable people to build things they’re proud of Project manager develops and leads effective Team by fostering a culture of Teamwork.

item.title: Projections
item.description: How you predict an outcome based on the information you have now.

item.title: Projects to avoid
item.description: Types of Project to avoid: Never-ending projects Abandoned projects Never-ending projects They exist when the project deliverables and tasks cannot be completed.

item.title: Qualitative and quantitative data
item.description: Types: Quantitative data: Specific and objective measures of numerical facts Qualitative data Tools: Qualitative Focus groups Social media text analysis In-person interview Quantitative Structured interviews Surveys Polls

item.title: Qualitative data
item.description: Subjective qualities that can’t be measured with numerical data. Subjective or explanatory measures of qualities and characteristics.

item.title: Quality
item.description: It is making sure that you deliver what you say you will, and that you do it as efficiently as you can.

item.title: Quality management
item.description: Benefits Delivery of a quality product Decreasing the overhead, therefore costs Increasing collaboration and ongoing reviews Types Quality standards Quality planning Quality assurance Quality control Quality standards Provide requirements, specifications, or guidelines that can be used to ensure that products, processes, or services are fit for achieving the desired outcome.

item.title: Quality planning
item.description: The process that the Project manager or the team establishes and follows for identifying and determining exactly which standards of Quality are relevant to the project as a whole, and how to satisfy them.

item.title: Quantitative data
item.description: Statistical and numerical facts.

item.title: Quartile
item.description: A quartile divides Data points into four equal parts.

item.title: Questions to avoid
item.description: Question types to avoid: Leading questions A question that steers people toward a certain response Closed-ended Yes/No questions Vague questions

item.title: RACI chart
item.description: A RACI chart helps to define roles and responsibilities for individuals or teams to ensure work gets done efficiently. Responsible Accountable Consulted Informed Responsible Those doing the work to complete the task Accountable Those making sure the work gets done Never more than one role can be accountable to clearly define ownership Consulted Those giving feedback, like subject matter experts or decisions makers Informed Those just needing to know the final decisions, or that a task is complete

item.title: Random sampling
item.description: It is a way of selecting a Sample from a Population so that every possible type of the sample has an equal chance of being chosen.

item.title: Reasons for Scrum's popularity
item.description: Reasons for Scrum’s popularity: Clear roles and responsibility, while continuously emphasizing the power of the team as a whole. Regular and predictable meeting and delivery schedules, formats, and outcomes.

item.title: Redundancy
item.description: When the same piece of Data is stored in two or more places.

item.title: Reframing
item.description: The process of restating a problem or challenge, then redirecting it toward a potential resolution.

item.title: Releasable
item.description: When the team has developed a Minimum Viable Product (MVP), which has a set of implemented features or requirements.

item.title: Release plans
item.description: The dates on which a team expects to release a given feature to customers or users. Release goal What you want to release List of backlog items Estimated release date Other relevant dates that impact a release Tips The Product owner and the Scrum Master must work together before releasing the plan Release plans need to connect the product roadmap with the team capacity and Velocity.

item.title: Relevant question
item.description: A question that has significance to the problem to be solved. Unfair question A question that makes assumptions or is difficult to answer honestly

item.title: Report
item.description: Static collection of data given to the Stakeholders periodically. Pros: high-level historical data easy to design pre-cleaned and sorted data Cons:

item.title: Retrospective
item.description: A workshop or meeting that gives project teams time to reflect on a project. Performed after a Project is completed.

item.title: Risk
item.description: A potential event that can occur and can impact your project. If a risk is potentially an event. If the event actually happens it becomes an Issue.

item.title: Risk appetite
item.description: The risk appetite is the willingness of an organization to accept the possible outcomes of a risk.

item.title: Risk exposure
item.description: A way to measure the potential future loss resulting from a specific activity or event.

item.title: Risk management
item.description: Risk management provides an understanding of: What could go wrong Who you’ll need to consult How the risk could be mitigated If you don’t plan ahead, you may put your project at risk of not meeting its project goal, its timelines, or its success criteria.

item.title: Risk management phases
item.description: Phases: Identify the risk. Analyze the risk. Evaluate the risk. Treat the risk. Monitor and control the risk. Identify the risk.

item.title: Risk management plan
item.description: A risk management plan is a living document that contains information regarding high-level risks and the mitigation plans for those risks.

item.title: Risk mitigation
item.description: Risk mitigation is a strategy to prepare for and lessen the effects of threats faced by a business. Four types of risk mitigation strategies:

item.title: Roadmap
item.description: Features: Useful for high-level tracking of large milestones Useful for illustrating how a project should evolve over time

item.title: Root cause
item.description: The root cause is the reason why a problem occurs Linked to: Five whys

item.title: Sample
item.description: A part of a Population that is representative of the population. Refs: Sampling bias Sample size Minimum 30.

item.title: Sampling bias
item.description: When a Sample isn’t representative of the Population as a whole. Refs: Data bias Opposite: Unbiased sampling

item.title: Scale agile
item.description: Frameworks: Scrum of Scrums Scaled Agile Framework (SAFe) Large-Scale Scrum (LeSS) Disciplined Agile Delivery (DAD) The Spotify Model Best practices Treat scaling models like SAFe, Scrum of Scrums, LeSS, etc.

item.title: Scaled Agile Framework (SAFe)
item.description: The most popular scaled framework is the Scaled Agile Framework or SAFe. SAFe is a Lean- Agile scaling framework that draws heavily on concepts from Kanban, Scrum, Extreme programming (XP), DevOps, and Design Thinking methodologies.

item.title: Scope
item.description: Topics: Managing project’s scope Project scope Scope creep Triple constraints model

item.title: Scope creep
item.description: Changes, growth, and uncontrolled factors affect a project‚Äôs scope at any point after the project begins. Scope creep sources: External Internal External Customer requests Environment shift Changes in technology Product improvements Process changes Solutions Make project plan visible Get clarity on project requirements Set group rules and expectations for stakeholder involvement Role and responsibility during execution and review Create a plan for dealing with out-of-scope requests Agree on who can make a request Put your agreements and plans in writing

item.title: Scope of Work
item.description: An agreed-upon outline of the work you’re going to perform on a project. It can include: Deliverables Timeline Milestones Reports Refs:

item.title: Scrum
item.description: Agile is the foundational philosophy and mindset, while Scrum is a framework that materializes or brings that philosophy to life.

item.title: Scrum events
item.description: Events: Sprint Sprint planning Daily Stand-up Sprint review Sprint retrospective Timeboxes Events are timeboxed:

item.title: Scrum Master
item.description: This role is responsible for ensuring that the team lives Agile Scrum values and Scrum principles, follows the processes and practices that the team agreed to, shares information with the larger project team, and also helps the team focus on doing their best work.

item.title: Scrum of Scrums
item.description: Scrum of Scrums is a technique for integrating the work of multiple, smaller Scrum teams working on the same project or solution.

item.title: Scrum pillars
item.description: Scrum pillars: Transparency Inspection Adaptation Transparency Make the most significant aspects of our work visible to those responsible for the outcome.

item.title: Scrum principles
item.description: Principles: Built-in instability Self-organizing teams Overlapping development phases Multi-learning Subtle control Organizational transfer of learning Built-in instability In the Scrum world, teams are given the freedom to achieve important outcomes with ‚Äúchallenging requirements.

item.title: Scrum roles
item.description: Scrum roles: Scrum Master Product owner Development team (or Developers) Scrum Teams are cross-functional. When a Scrum Team delivers something, it’s the accomplishment of the entire team.

item.title: Scrum values
item.description: Scrum values: Commitment Courage Focus Openness Respect Commitment Personally committing to achieving the goals of the Scrum team.

item.title: Second-party data
item.description: Data collected by a group directly from its audience then sold

item.title: Share
item.description: Avoiding misleading or deceptive charts Curse of knowledge Design principles Design thinking Dynamic visualizations Effective data visualization Elements for effective visuals Elements of art Engagement Further reading Hypothesis Powerful visualization Tableau The McCandless method Why data visualization mattera

item.title: Signal
item.description: An observable change that helps determine the overall health of the project and identify early signs that something isn’t quite right.

item.title: Six Sigma
item.description: Used to reduce variations by ensuring that quality processes are followed every time. The term ‚ÄúSix Sigma‚Äù originates from statistics and generally means that items or processes should have 99.

item.title: Small data
item.description: Characteristics: Specific Short time-period Day-to-day decision Usually organized and analyzed in spreadsheets Simple to collect, store, manage, sort, and visually represent

item.title: SMART
item.description: SMART: Specific Measurable - To objectively meet the goal Attainable (or Action-oriented) Relevant Time-bound Specific What do I want to accomplish?

item.title: SMART questions
item.description: Effective questions follow the SMART methodology. Specific A question that is simple, significant, and focused on a single topic or a few closely related ideas is the question specific?

item.title: Soft skills
item.description: Soft skills are personal characteristics¬†that help people work effectively with others. Negotiation Empathetic listening Understand their frustration Address those frustration Find a solution that’s beneficial for both of you Trust-building

item.title: Sources of power to influence
item.description: Two buckets of power sources of Influencing: Organizational Personal Organizational Role Your position within an organization or team Information Your level of access and control over information Network The people you’re connected with, professionally and personally Reputation How others perceive you Personal Knowledge The power you draw from your expertise in certain subjects, your unique abilities and skill sets, and your ability to learn new things Expressiveness Your ability to communicate with others History The level of personal history that exists between you and another person Character Other people’s view of your personal qualities

item.title: Sponsor
item.description: A professional advocate who’s committed to moving a sponsee’s career forward within an organization. A sponsor helps you move up.

item.title: Sprint
item.description: The Sprint is the name of the time-boxed period in Scrum where work is done. Within a Sprint, the amount of work is planned based on the historical capacity of the team and is made ready for the Sprint planning event.

item.title: Sprint backlog
item.description: The sprint backlog is the set of Product backlog items that are identified for completion during the upcoming Sprint.

item.title: Sprint planning
item.description: The entire Scrum Team comes together and meets to confirm how much capacity, meaning time and people, are available during the Sprint.

item.title: Sprint retrospective
item.description: An essential meeting of up to 3 hours for the Scrum Team to take a step back, reflect, and identify improvements about how to work together as a team.

item.title: Sprint review
item.description: Done at the end of the Sprint. A meeting with the entire Scrum Team where the product is demonstrated in order to determine which aspects are finished and which aren’t.

item.title: Stakeholder analysis
item.description: Analysis: Make a list of all the Stakeholders the project impacts Determine the level of interest and influence for each stakeholder Interest is how much are the needs of the stakeholder affected by the project operations and outcomes Influence measures how much power a stakeholder has and how much this stakeholder‚Äôs action affects the project outcome Assess stakeholders‚Äô ability to participate and then find ways to involve them Beyond clarifying who your stakeholders are, the stakeholders’ analysis helps:

item.title: Stakeholder management
item.description: Stakeholder management is the process of maintaining good relationships with the people who have the most influence on your work.

item.title: Stakeholders
item.description: People who are interested in and affected by the project‚Äôs completion and success. People that have invested time, interest, and resources into the project.

item.title: Statement of Work (SoW)
item.description: A document that clearly lays out the products and services a vendor or contractor will provide for the organization. It has to include Vendors and Organization needs.

item.title: Statistical power
item.description: The probability of getting meaningful results from a test. Generally, you need a statistical power of at least 0.8 (80%) to consider your results statistically significant ( Statistical significance)

item.title: Statistical significance
item.description: The determination of whether your result could be due to random chance or not. The greater the significance, the less due to chance.

item.title: Steps to effective influencing
