item.description: Dr. Jay A. Conger’s steps to effective influencing. Establish credibility Frame for common ground Provide evidence Connect emotionally Establish credibility Make the case for why your audience should listen to you.

item.title: Storytelling
item.description: The process of turning facts into a narrative to communicate something to your audience. Many experts believe that human brains automatically organize events¬†with a beginning, a middle, and an end.

item.title: Structured data
item.description: Data organized in a certain format such as rows and columns. Tools to store structured data: Spreadsheets Relational databases Opposite:

item.title: Structured thinking
item.description: Structured thinking is the process of recognizing the current problem or situation, organizing available information, revealing gaps and opportunities, and identifying options.

item.title: Subject-matter experts
item.description: People very familiar with the business problem. Roles: Identify inconsistencies in the analysis Offer insights into the business problem Validate the choices being made

item.title: Success criteria
item.description: Criteria: Tells you whether or not the project was successful Specific details of project goals, deliverables, requirements, and expectations The standards by which the project will be judged once it‚Äôs been delivered to stakeholders Determining project success:

item.title: T-shaped team
item.description: A team that includes different kinds of professionals working toward a common goal. Clarify goals Get team members with the right skills Measure progress Recognize efforts

item.title: Tableau
item.description: A business intelligence and analytics platform that helps people see, understand and make decisions with data.

item.title: Tasks
item.description: An activity that needs to be accomplished within a set period. Sub-task Smaller tasks that are required to complete a larger task.

item.title: Tasks dependencies
item.description: A relationship between two project tasks, where the start or completion of one depends on the start or completion of the other.

item.title: Team
item.description: A group of people who plan, solve problems, make decisions, and review progress in service of a specific Project or objective.

item.title: Team development
item.description: Bruce Truckman’s stage of Team development: Forming Storming Norming Performing Adjourning Forming Team gets to know one another Project manager should clarify the project goals, roles, and context of the project Done during the Make a plan project phase.

item.title: Team dynamics
item.description: The forces, both conscious and unconscious, that impact Team behavior and performance. Why managing team dynamics is important Teams have individuals with different skill sets, varying degrees of autonomy, and competing priorities Create a collaborative a psychologically safe environment [Team effectiveness factors](danielesalvatore/project-management/project-execution/effective-teams/team-effectiveness-factors.

item.title: Team effectiveness factors
item.description: Factors: Psychological safety Dependability Structure and clarity Meaning Impact Psychological safety An individual’s perception of the consequences of taking an interpersonal risk Google culture: Be direct AND kind Dependability Teas members are reliable and complete their work on time Structure and clarity An individual’s understanding of job expectations, knowledge of how to meet those expectations, and the consequences of their performance.

item.title: Team members
item.description: The people doing the work and making things happen.

item.title: Teamwork
item.description: An effective, collaborative way of working in which each person is committed to and heading toward a shared goal.

item.title: Techniques to help manage risks
item.description: If you can manage Change, Tasks dependencies, and Scope creep other types of risks become much easier to manage. If your dependencies are met on time, your team is less likely to fall behind schedule.

item.title: The closing process for the project manager
item.description: Processes: Write the Closeout report

item.title: The closing process for the team
item.description: Processes: Run Retrospective [High-functioning teams](danielesalvatore/project-management/project-execution/effective-teams/high-functioning-teams.md#Promote trust and psychological safety) to gather transparent feedback Links: Project closing

item.title: The McCandless method
item.description: From generic to specific. Method: Introduce the graphic by name (i.e., use titles) Answer obvious questions before they’re asked State the insight of your graphic Call out data to support that insight Tell your audience why it matters Present the possible business impact of the solution and clear actions Stakeholders can take Ref:

item.title: The Spotify Model
item.description: Another approach you may encounter is the ‚ÄúSpotify Model,‚Äù which we discussed in a previous reading. It is important to note that Spotify‚Äôs model is not a true Agile framework.

item.title: Third-party data
item.description: Data collected from outside sources who did not collect it directly.

item.title: Time & materials contracts
item.description: Paid monthly based on the hours worked and other fees associated with the work, like travel and meals.

item.title: Tips for effective communication
item.description: Tips: Recognize and understand individual differences Brainstorm and craft the appropriate message Deliver your message Obtain feedback and incorporate that feedback going forward Links:

item.title: Tools to identify risks
item.description: Brainstorming Spontaneously share ideas without judgment between the team to identify risks. Invite to brainstorm with diverse team members. Cause-and-effect diagram A diagram that shows the possible causes of an event or risk.

item.title: Tracking
item.description: A method of following the progress of project activities. Track Deviation. Tracking’s benefits: Tracking makes transparent the key information of a project.

item.title: Tracking methods
item.description: Examples: Gantt chart Roadmap Burndown chart

item.title: Triple constraints model
item.description: Constraints: Scope Time Project schedule and deadline Cost Budget and people working on a project

item.title: Type of costs
item.description: Account for both direct costs and indirect costs in your project budget. Direct costs Indirect costs (overhead costs) Direct costs Costs for items that are necessary in order to complete your project.

item.title: Type of risks
item.description: Common risks types: Time risks The possibility that project tasks will take longer than anticipated to complete. Refers to Project schedule Budget risks The possibility that the costs of a project will increase due to poor Project planning or expanding the project’s scope.

item.title: Types of project meetings
item.description: Types: Project kick-off Status updates Stakeholders reviews Project reviews Project kick-off A project kick-off meeting is the official beginning of a project and serves as a way to align the team’s understanding of the project goals with actual plans and procedures.

item.title: Unbiased sampling
item.description: When a Sample is representative of a Population being measured. Opposite: Sampling bias

item.title: Unstructured data
item.description: Data that is not organized in any easily identifiable manner. Examples of unstructured data: Audio files Video files Opposite:

item.title: User acceptable tests (UAT)
item.description: A test that helps a business make sure a product or solution works for its users. UAT agenda steps Welcome users and thank them for participating.

item.title: User stories
item.description: User stories are concise, specific descriptions of a feature told from the user‚Äôs perspective. They allow the team to create solutions centered on the user experience and help project managers capture and manage the Product backlog.

item.title: Users
item.description: Users People who will ultimately use the product produced by your project. Customer The people who will get some value from a successfully landed project.

item.title: Validity
item.description: The degree to which Data conforms to constraints when it is input, collected, or created.

item.title: Value
item.description: Value can mean different things for each customer based on what they expect the product to accomplish. Links: [Agile manifesto](danielesalvatore/project-management/agile-project-management/agile-manifesto.

item.title: Value of data
item.description: To use Data to help us make decisions and improve performance. Benefits of using data: Make better decisions Solve problems Understand performance Improve processes

item.title: Value roadmap
item.description: Value roadmap: An Agile way of mapping out the product development process It can be used for all types of business A guide that demonstrates Where to go How to get there What to accomplish along the way in order to maximize the Value It has three components:

item.title: Value-driven delivery
item.description: Value-driven delivery means you and your team are focused on delivering a product of high Value. How to ensure you are building something value-driven:

item.title: Velocity
item.description: The measure of how many points the team burns down in a given Sprint. Often calculated as the average of the last three sprints.

item.title: Vendors
item.description: Individuals or businesses who provide essential goods and services. Vendor management It includes: Sourcing vendors Getting quotes for vendors’ work Deciphering which vendors will fulfill your needs Negotiating vendor contracts Setting deadlines for vendors Evaluating performance Ensuring vendors are paid

item.title: VUCA
item.description: VUCA is an acronym that defines the conditions that affect organizations in a changing and complex world. Volatility Uncertainty Complexity Ambiguity Volatility Volatility refers to the rate of change and churns in a business or situation Uncertainty Uncertainty refers to the lack of¬†predictability or high potential for surprise.

item.title: Waterfall
item.description: The waterfall approach is an ordered series of steps. Phases: Initiating Planning Execution and completion of the tasks Closing out the projects When you want to use waterfall:

item.title: Why data visualization mattera
item.description: Data visualization Scientists and mathematicians began to truly embrace the idea of arranging Data Analysts/Foundations/Data visually in the 1700s and 1800s.

item.title: Why project initialization is important
item.description: A strong foundation for the project The initial phase is a crucial time for asking stakeholders the right questions, performing research, determining resources, and clearly documenting the key component of a project.

item.title: Wide data
item.description: A Dataset in which every data subject has a single row with multiple columns to hold the values of various attributes of the subject

item.title: Work breakdown structure (WBS)
item.description: A tool that sorts the milestones and tasks of a project in a hierarchy in the order they need to be completed.

item.title: Work in Progress
item.description: Work in progress Limit Tasks are limited to what the team can actually handle during a certain amount of time.

item.title: Workgroups
item.description: People in an organization who work toward a common goal. Work groups are more likely to be coordinated, controlled, or assigned by a single person or entry.

item.title: Wrap-ups
item.description: I am excited to share with you my Google Project Management: Professional Certificate! I decided to complete this specialization, available at https://www.

item.title: Writing emails to escalate a problem
item.description: Escalation email tips: Think about what’s most important to Stakeholders Identify how a problem will impact the organization as a whole and ensure you clearly communicate the impact within the first two sentences of your email Write a clear subject line Include language in your subject line that indicates what you’d like your stakeholder to do upon reading your email keep the body of the email brief and to the point Consider including hyperlinks or attachments with that information in your email Proofread for misspellings, grammatical errors, and inaccurate hyperlinks.
